functions.description: Execute all handlers and behaviors attached to the figure for the given event type.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: the event to trigger

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: getBestChild
functions.description: Returns the best figure at the location [x,y]. It is a simple hit test. Keep in mind that only visible objects are returned.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: figureToIgnore
parameters.description: The figures which should be ignored.

functions.name: init
functions.description: Creates a new figure element which are not assigned to any canvas.

parameters.name: attr
parameters.description: the configuration of the shape

functions.name: setPath
functions.description: Set the image path attribute of the Image shape and repaint them. The path can be relative or absolute

functions.name: getPath
functions.description: Return the image path attribute of the shape.

functions.name: setPersistPorts
functions.description: Indicates if the node should read/write the ports via the draw2d.Figure.getPersistenAttributes to the JSON object

functions.name: getPersistPorts
functions.description: Indicates if the figure writes the ports to the JSON structore too. Default is "false"

functions.name: toFront
functions.description:
Moves the element so it is the closest to the viewer’s eyes, on top of other elements. Additional the internal model changed as well.

Optional: Inserts current object in front of the given one.

parameters.name: figure
parameters.description: move current object in front of the given one.

functions.name: toBack
functions.description: Moves the element to the background. Additional the internal model changed as well.

functions.name: setVisible
functions.description:
Show/hide the element. The element didn't receive any mouse events (click, dblclick) if you hide the figure.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  visible: flag
});

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: the optional number for the fadeIn /fadeOut of the figure

functions.name: getPorts
functions.description: Return all ports of the node. The results contains all ports of the children too per default. Set recursive to false to retrieve direct assigned ports only.

parameters.name: recursive
parameters.description: indicates if the method should return children ports too. Default is true

functions.name: getInputPorts
functions.description: Return all input ports of the node.

functions.name: getOutputPorts
functions.description: Return all output ports of the node.

functions.name: clone
functions.description:
Clone the figure.
You must override and implement the methods getPersistentAttributes and setPersistentAttributes for your custom figures if the have special attributes.

The clone() method performs a deep copy of the object, meaning that it copies the children, ports and decorations per default. You can control the clone procedure with the 'cloneMetaData'.

parameters.name: cloneMetaData
parameters.description: controls the clone procedure

parameters.name: cloneMetaData.excludeChildren
parameters.description: set it to true if you want exclude the children.

parameters.name: cloneMetaData.excludePorts
parameters.description: set it to true if you want exclude the ports of the node.

functions.name: getPort
functions.description: Return the port with the corresponding name.

parameters.name: portName
parameters.description: The name of the port to return.

returns.description: Returns the port with the hands over name or null.

functions.name: getInputPort
functions.description: Return the input port with the corresponding name.

parameters.name: portNameOrIndex
parameters.description: The name or numeric index of the port to return.

returns.description: Returns the port with the hands over name or null.

functions.name: getOutputPort
functions.description: Return the output port with the corresponding name.

parameters.name: portNameOrIndex
parameters.description: The name or the numeric index of the port to return.

returns.description: Returns the port with the hands over name or null.

functions.name: getHybridPort
functions.description: Return the input port with the corresponding name.

parameters.name: portNameOrIndex
parameters.description: The name or numeric index of the port to return.

returns.description: Returns the port with the hands over name or null.

functions.name: addPort
functions.description: Add a port to this node at the given position.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The new port to add.

parameters.name: locator
parameters.description: The layout for the port.

functions.name: resetPorts
functions.description: Remove all ports of this node

functions.name: removePort
functions.description: Removes a port and all related connections from this node.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to remove.

functions.name: createPort
functions.description: Create a standard Port for this element. Inherited class can override this method to create its own type of ports.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: the type of the requested port. possible ["input", "output"]

parameters.name: locator
parameters.description: the layouter to use for this port

functions.name: getConnections
functions.description: Return all connections related to this node.

functions.name: onPortValueChanged
functions.description: Called if the value of any port has been changed

functions.name: createCommand
functions.description: Returns the Command to perform the specified Request or null.

parameters.name: request
parameters.description: describes the Command being requested

functions.name: getPersistentAttributes
functions.description: Return an objects with all important attributes for XML or JSON serialization

functions.name: setPersistentAttributes
functions.description: Read all attributes from the serialized properties and transfer them into the shape.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.name: select
functions.description: Add the figure to the current selection and propagate this to all edit policies.

parameters.name: asPrimarySelection
parameters.description: true if the element should be the primary selection

functions.name: unselect
functions.description: Unselect the figure and propagete this event to all edit policies.

functions.name: setSelectionAdapter
functions.description: Returns a function which returns the the figure which must handle the selection handling.

parameters.name: adapter
parameters.description: function which returns the figure which handles the selection handling

functions.name: isSelected
functions.description: Returns true if the figure part of the current canvas selection.

functions.name: setUserData
functions.description:
Allows a user to attach (or remove) data to an element, without needing to create a custom figure or shape. The data must be a valid JSON object.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  userData: object
});

functions.name: getUserData
functions.description: Returns any user data set previously on the given figure by setUserData.

functions.name: getId
functions.description: Return the UUID of this element.

functions.name: setId
functions.description:
Set the id of this element.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method: figure.attr({ id: newId });

parameters.name: newId
parameters.description: the new id for this figure

functions.name: getCssClass
functions.description: Return the css styling class name of the element.

functions.name: setCssClass
functions.description:
Set the css class of the node.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  "cssClass": "red_border_figure"
});

parameters.name: cssClass
parameters.description: the new css class name of the node

functions.name: hasCssClass
functions.description: The method will return true if the class is assigned to the element, even if other classes also are.

parameters.name: className
parameters.description: the class name to check

functions.name: addCssClass
functions.description:
Add a CSS class to the figure.
It's important to note that this method does not replace a class. It simply adds the class, appending it to any which may already be assigned to the elements.

functions.name: removeCssClass
functions.description: Remove the given css class name from the figure

parameters.name: className
parameters.description: the css class name to add

functions.name: toggleCssClass
functions.description: Add or remove the given css class name from the figure

parameters.name: className
parameters.description: the class name to toggle

functions.name: getCanvas
functions.description: Return the current assigned canvas container.

functions.name: startTimer
functions.description: Start a timer which calls the onTimer method in the given interval.

functions.name: stopTimer
functions.description: Stop the internal timer.

functions.name: onTimer
functions.description:
Callback method for the internal timer handling
Inherit classes must override this method if they want use the timer feature.

// Alternatively you can register for this event with
figure.on("timer", function(emitter){
    alert("timer fired");
});

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.name: uninstallEditPolicy
functions.description: UnInstall the edit policy from the figure. Either the instance itself if found or all kind of the given edit policies.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: the figure to add as decoration to the connection.

parameters.name: locator
parameters.description: the locator for the child.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: optional index where to insert the figure

functions.name: remove
functions.description: Remove the child figure from this figure and the canvas

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: the figure to remove.

returns.description: the removed tupple of figure/locator or null if the child isn't found

functions.name: getChildren
functions.description: Return all children/decorations of this shape which has been added with draw2d.Figure.add

functions.name: resetChildren
functions.description: Remove all children/decorations of this shape

functions.name: getShapeElement
functions.description: return the current SVG shape element or create it on demand.

functions.name: getTopLevelShapeElement
functions.description:
Get the top level shape element. May the figure has a set of SVG elements. In this case this method must return the top level node.
This method is used for the toFront/toBack method to order the nodes in the correct way.

functions.name: createShapeElement
functions.description: Inherited classes must override this method to implement it's own draw functionality.

functions.name: applyTransformation
functions.description: apply a transformation to the shape like rotation, translate,..

functions.name: setGlow
functions.description:
Highlight the element or remove the highlighting

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  glow: flag
});

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: indicates glow/noGlow

functions.name: getHandleBBox
functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: onDragStart
functions.description: Called if the drag and drop action begins. You can return [false] if you want avoid that the figure can be move.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onDrag
functions.description:
Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: the x difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: the x difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanningEnd
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panningEnd", function(emitter){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: onDragEnd
functions.description:
Will be called after a drag and drop action.
Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super();

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate of the mouse event

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate of the mouse event

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: delegateTarget
functions.description: Called by the framework during drag&drop operations if the user drag a figure over this figure

parameters.name: draggedFigure
parameters.description: The figure which is currently dragging

returns.description: the figure which should receive the drop event or null if the element didn't want a drop event

functions.name: onDragEnter
functions.description: Called by the framework during drag&drop operations if the user drag a figure over this figure

parameters.name: draggedFigure
parameters.description: The figure which is currently dragging

functions.name: onDragLeave
functions.description: Called if the DragDrop object leaving the current hover figure.

parameters.name: draggedFigure
parameters.description: The figure which is currently dragging

functions.name: onDrop
functions.description: Called if the user drop this element onto the dropTarget. This event is ONLY fired if the shape return "this" in the {@link draw2d.Figure#onDragEnter} method.

parameters.name: dropTarget
parameters.description: The drop target.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onCatch
functions.description: Called if the user dropped an figure onto this element. This event is ONLY fired if the in the canvas installed {@link draw2d.policy.canvas.DropInterceptorPolicy} allow this.

parameters.name: droppedFigure
parameters.description: The dropped figure.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onMouseEnter
functions.description: Callback method for the mouse enter event. Usefull for mouse hover-effects. Override this method for your own effects. Don't call them manually.

functions.name: onMouseLeave
functions.description: Callback method for the mouse leave event. Useful for mouse hover-effects.

functions.name: onDoubleClick
functions.description:
Called when a user dbl clicks on the element

// Alternatively you can register an event with:
//
figure.on("dblclick", function(emitter, event){
    alert("user dbl click on the figure");
});

functions.name: onClick
functions.description:
Called when a user clicks on the element.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("click", function(emitter, event){
    alert("user click on the figure");
});

functions.name: onContextMenu
functions.description:
called by the framework if the figure should show the context menu.
The strategy to show the context menu depends on the platform. Either looong press or right click with the mouse.

// Alternatively you register for this event with:
figure.on("contextmenu", function(emitter, event){
    alert("user press the right mouse button for a context menu");
});

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate to show the menu

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate to show the menu

functions.name: setAlpha
functions.description:
Set the alpha blending of this figure.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  "alpha": percent
});

// ...or:
figure.attr({
  "opacity": percent
});

parameters.name: percent
parameters.description: value between [0..1].

functions.name: getAlpha
functions.description: Return the alpha blending of the figure

functions.name: getRotationAngle
functions.description:
return the rotation angle of the figure in degree of [0..356].


NOTE: this method is pre alpha and not for production. Only steps of 90 degree is working well

functions.name: isVisible
functions.description: Return true if the figure visible.

functions.name: setKeepAspectRatio
functions.description: Guarantee, that the figure width/height will not be distorted. Applicable before calling setDimension(). It is false by default.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: boolean flag if the figure should respect the aspect ratio

functions.name: getKeepAspectRatio
functions.description: Return the flag if the shape keep the aspect ratio.

functions.name: getZOrder
functions.description: Return the current z-index of the element. Currently this is an expensive method. The index will be calculated all the time. Caching is not implemented at the moment.

functions.name: setCanSnapToHelper
functions.description: Set the flag if this object can snap to grid or geometry. A window of dialog should set this flag to false.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The snap to grid/geometry enable flag.

functions.name: getCanSnapToHelper
functions.description: Returns true if the figure can snap to any helper like a grid, guide, geometrie or something else.

functions.name: setSnapToGridAnchor
functions.description: Set the hot spot for all snapTo### operations.

functions.name: setWidth
functions.description: Set the width of the figure and consider the minWidth attribute

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: the new width of the figure

functions.name: getWidth
functions.description: The current width of the figure.

functions.name: setHeight
functions.description: Set the heigth of the figure and consider the minWidth attribute

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: the new height of the figure

functions.name: getHeight
functions.description: The current height of the figure.

functions.name: getMinWidth
functions.description: This value is relevant for the interactive resize of the figure.

returns.description: Returns the min. width of this object.

functions.name: setMinWidth
functions.description: Set the minimum width of this figure

functions.name: getMinHeight
functions.description: This value is relevant for the interactive resize of the figure.

returns.description: Returns the min. height of this object.

functions.name: setMinHeight
functions.description: Set the minimum height of the figure.

functions.name: setX
functions.description: the the x-offset related to the parent figure or canvas

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the new x offset of the figure

functions.name: getX
functions.description: The x-offset related to the parent figure or canvas.

functions.name: setY
functions.description: the the y-offset related to the parent figure or canvas

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the new x offset of the figure

functions.name: getY
functions.description: The y-offset related to the parent figure or canvas.

functions.name: getAbsoluteX
functions.description: The x-offset related to the canvas.

functions.name: getAbsoluteY
functions.description: The y-offset related to the canvas.

functions.name: getAbsolutePosition
functions.description: Returns the absolute y-position of the port.

functions.name: getAbsoluteBounds
functions.description: Returns the absolute y-position of the port.

functions.name: setPosition
functions.description:
Set the position of the object.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  x: x,
  y: y
});

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x coordinate of the figure or the x/y coordinate if it is an draw2d.geo.Point

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y coordinate of the figure

functions.name: getPosition
functions.description: Get the current position of the figure

functions.name: translate
functions.description: Translate the figure with the given x/y offset.

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: The x offset to translate

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: The y offset to translate

functions.name: setBoundingBox
functions.description:
Set the bounding box of the figure

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  width: w,
  height: h,
  x: x,
  y: y
});

// or
figure.attr({
  boundingBox: {x:1, y:100, width:30, height:30}
});

functions.name: getBoundingBox
functions.description: Returns the bounding box of the figure in absolute position to the canvas.

functions.name: getOuterBoundingBox
functions.description: Returns the bounding box of the figure in absolute position to the canvas. All child shapes included. The result BoundingBox spans the parent figured plus all children.

functions.name: hitTest
functions.description: Detect whenever the hands over coordinate is inside the figure. The default implementation is a simple bounding box test.

functions.name: setDraggable
functions.description: Switch on/off the drag drop behaviour of this object

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The new drag drop indicator

functions.name: isDraggable
functions.description: Get the Drag drop enable flag

functions.name: isResizeable
functions.description: Returns the true if the figure can be resized.

functions.name: setResizeable
functions.description:
You can change the resizeable behaviour of this object. Hands over [false] and the figure has no resizehandles if you select them with the mouse.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  resizeable: flag
});

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The resizeable flag.

functions.name: isSelectable
functions.description: Indicates whenever the element is selectable by user interaction or API.

functions.name: setSelectable
functions.description: You can change the selectable behavior of this object. Hands over [false] and the figure has no selection handles if you try to select them with the mouse.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The selectable flag.

functions.name: isStrechable
functions.description:
Return true if the object doesn't care about the aspect ratio. You can change the height and width independent.

Replaced with "getKeepAspectRatio"

functions.name: isDeleteable
functions.description: Return false if you avoid that the user can delete your figure. Sub class can override this method.

functions.name: setDeleteable
functions.description: Set the flag if the shape is deleteable.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: enable or disable flag for the delete operation

functions.name: setParent
functions.description: Set the parent of this figure. Don't call them manually.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The new parent of this figure

functions.name: getParent
functions.description: Get the parent of this figure.

functions.name: contains
functions.description:
Check to see if a figure is a descendant of another figure.
The contains() method returns true if the figure provided by the argument is a descendant of this figure, whether it is a direct child or nested more deeply. Otherwise, it returns false.

parameters.name: containedFigure
parameters.description: The figure that may be contained by (a descendant of) this figure.

functions.name: getRoot
functions.description: Get the top most parent of this figure. This can be an layout figure or parent container

functions.name: setComposite
functions.description: Set the assigned composite of this figure.

parameters.name: composite
parameters.description: The assigned composite of this figure

functions.name: getComposite
functions.description: Get the assigned composite of this figure.

functions.name: fireEvent
functions.description: Execute all handlers and behaviors attached to the figure for the given event type.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: the event to trigger

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: getBestChild
functions.description: Returns the best figure at the location [x,y]. It is a simple hit test. Keep in mind that only visible objects are returned.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: figureToIgnore
parameters.description: The figures which should be ignored.

functions.name: init
functions.description: Creates a new text element.

parameters.name: attr
parameters.description: the configuration of the shape

functions.name: setFontFamily
functions.description:
Set the font family to use. If you use the shown font names the typical fallback font are installed as well.

Serif Fonts

  • Georgia
  • Palatino Linotype
  • Times New Roman

Sans-Serif Fonts

  • Arial
  • Arial Black
  • Comic Sans MS
  • Impact, Charcoal
  • Lucida Sans Unicode
  • Tahoma, Geneva
  • Trebuchet MS
  • Verdana

Monospace Fonts

  • Courier New
  • Lucida Console

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The font to use

functions.name: clone
functions.description:
Clone the figure.
You must override and implement the methods getPersistentAttributes and setPersistentAttributes for your custom figures if the have special attributes.

The clone() method performs a deep copy of the object, meaning that it copies the children, ports and decorations per default. You can control the clone procedure with the 'cloneMetaData'.

parameters.name: cloneMetaData
parameters.description: controls the clone procedure

parameters.name: cloneMetaData.excludeChildren
parameters.description: set it to true if you want exclude the children.

parameters.name: cloneMetaData.excludePorts
parameters.description: set it to true if you want exclude the ports of the node.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

});

functions.description:
Add a CSS class to the figure.
It's important to note that this method does not replace a class. It simply adds the class, appending it to any which may already be assigned to the elements.

functions.description:
Callback method for the internal timer handling
Inherit classes must override this method if they want use the timer feature.

figure.on("timer", function(emitter){
    alert("timer fired");
});

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.name: uninstallEditPolicy
functions.description: UnInstall the edit policy from the figure. Either the instance itself if found or all kind of the given edit policies.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: the figure to add as decoration to the connection.

parameters.name: locator
parameters.description: the locator for the child.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: optional index where to insert the figure

functions.name: remove
functions.description: Remove the child figure from this figure and the canvas

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: the figure to remove.

returns.description: the removed tupple of figure/locator or null if the child isn't found

functions.name: getHandleBBox
functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: onDragStart
functions.description: Called if the drag and drop action begins. You can return [false] if you want avoid that the figure can be move.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y-coordinate of the mouse up event

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onDrag
functions.description:
Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: the x difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: the x difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanningEnd
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panningEnd", function(emitter){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

canvas.add( start);

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.description: optional event related data

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

canvas.add( start);

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

parameters.description: optional index where to insert the figure

functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dx

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the mouse down operation and now

Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:

    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: onContextMenu
functions.description:
called by the framework if the figure should show the context menu.
The strategy to show the context menu depends on the platform. Either looong press or right click with the mouse.

// Alternatively you register for this event with:

    alert("user press the right mouse button for a context menu");
});

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick
functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dy

Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:

    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: setAlpha
functions.description:
Set the alpha blending of this figure.

functions.name: on

Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu

  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: context

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

canvas.add( start);

Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

canvas.add( start);

Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • timer
  • contextmenu

  • hide

  • removed

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

You must override and implement the methods getPersistentAttributes and setPersistentAttributes for your custom figures if the have special attributes.

The clone() method performs a deep copy of the object, meaning that it copies the children, ports and decorations per default. You can control the clone procedure with the 'cloneMetaData'.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: getCanvas

functions.name: startTimer
functions.description: Start a timer which calls the onTimer method in the given interval.

functions.description: Stop the internal timer.

functions.name: onTimer
functions.description:
Callback method for the internal timer handling
Inherit classes must override this method if they want use the timer feature.

// Alternatively you can register for this event with
figure.on("timer", function(emitter){
    alert("timer fired");
});

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.name: uninstallEditPolicy
functions.description: UnInstall the edit policy from the figure. Either the instance itself if found or all kind of the given edit policies.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: the figure to add as decoration to the connection.

parameters.name: locator
parameters.description: the locator for the child.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: optional index where to insert the figure

functions.description: Remove the child figure from this figure and the canvas

parameters.description: the figure to remove.

returns.description: the removed tupple of figure/locator or null if the child isn't found

functions.name: getHandleBBox
functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.description:
Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dy

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanningEnd
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panningEnd", function(emitter){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

You must override and implement the methods getPersistentAttributes and setPersistentAttributes for your custom figures if the have special attributes.
